text: Okay, boys and girls, so tomorrow for math we are actually going to be playing a game using our fraction tracks game board that Student Y is passing out right now.  Our goal today is, we are going to be completing this game board. So we need to take our prior knowledge about percents and equivalent fractions and we’re going to apply them today and complete this game board, so that tomorrow we can play the game successfully.  But it is extremely important that we are accurate on this game board in labeling all of our fractions.  If we’re not accurate, then tomorrow when we go to play the game it will not be very successful.  So everybody should have a copy of this fraction tracts game board sheet. Now I know we’re having some difficulties with our projector screen, so I will put it on the blackboard.  If you can’t see it, it is okay, you have one in front of you. And we will be discussing and doing some of this together, then you’ll be on your own working with your partners to complete the game board.  So if you cannot see the overhead board, that’s fine, just use the one that you have in front of you.  Okay? So now everybody has a game board in front of them.  Take a minute.  Look it over.  What do you notice? Think about it? Give you a minute, then we’ll raise our hands to answer. What do you notice about this game board? Are there any similarities to any other resources that we have created? Just give yourself a minute. Does anybody want to share with me what they notice about this game board? Student G?
speaker: teacher

text: They all will add up to a whole.

text: So all the pieces will add up to a whole.  Good.  What other similarities do we notice? Student I?

But we’re going to call them today, fraction tracks, because that’s the name of the game that we’re going to be playing tomorrow. Okay? So if you look, we have a fraction track for halves, thirds, fourths, fifths, sixths, eighths, and tenths.  Does everybody see that? So what we’re going to do now is, we are going to go over the first one, the fraction track for halves.  And today you have a couple supplies that you can use. You will be able to use a small ruler and your pencil.  And what I’m going to do now is, I’m going to put this on the overhead and we’re going to talk about the halves, and we’re going to do a couple of them together, and we’re going to see what we notice.  Then we are going to use our strategies and we’re going to work with our partners to fill them out. Okay.  So remember, if you cannot see this board, and I know it’s difficult because we are having some difficulties with our overhead screen. So look at the top fraction track, and it is representing halves.  So you’re starting on the left-hand size, zero halves.  Okay? And I’m going to show you something using this ruler.  If I use this ruler, and everybody follow along with me, and I put it right on that one-half mark that’s already marked for me. Does everybody see that? Go ahead and do it on your own game board. We knew that one-half was also equal to two-fourths, three- sixths, four-eighths and five-tenths.  So when we were filling out our half stop, we could fill out other ones as well.
